sn45.28:1.2.pli: “Ariyaṃ vo, bhikkhave, sammāsamādhiṃ desessāmi saupanisaṃ saparikkhāraṃ.
sn45.28:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you noble right immersion with its vital conditions and its prerequisites.

sn45.28:1.4.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, ariyo sammāsamādhi saupaniso saparikkhāro?
sn45.28:1.4.eng: And what is noble right immersion with its vital conditions and its prerequisites?

sn45.28:1.5.eng: There are right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, and right mindfulness.

sn45.28:1.6.pli: Yā kho, bhikkhave, imehi sattahaṅgehi cittassa ekaggatā saparikkhāratā—
sn45.28:1.6.eng: Unification of mind with these seven factors as prerequisites is called noble right immersion ‘with its vital conditions’ and ‘with its prerequisites’.”

sn45.28:1.7.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyo sammāsamādhi saupaniso itipi saparikkhāro itipī”ti.

sn45.29:1.4.pli: Sukhā vedanā, dukkhā vedanā, adukkhamasukhā vedanā—

sn45.29:1.6.pli: Imāsaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tissannaṃ vedanānaṃ pariññāya ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvetabbo.
sn45.29:1.6.eng: The noble eightfold path should be developed to completely understand these three feelings.

sn45.29:1.7.eng: What is the noble eightfold path?

sn45.29:1.8.eng: It is right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.29:1.9.pli: Imāsaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tissannaṃ vedanānaṃ pariññāya ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvetabbo”ti.
sn45.29:1.9.eng: This noble eightfold path should be developed to completely understand these three feelings.”

sn45.3:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn45.3:1.2.eng: Then Sāriputta went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn45.3:1.3.eng: “Sir, good friends, companions, and associates are the whole of the spiritual life.”

sn45.3:2.2.pli: Sakalamidaṃ, sāriputta, brahmacariyaṃ, yadidaṃ—kalyāṇamittatā kalyāṇasahāyatā kalyāṇasampavaṅkatā.
sn45.3:2.2.eng: Good friends, companions, and associates are the whole of the spiritual life.

sn45.3:2.3.pli: Kalyāṇamittassetaṃ, sāriputta, bhikkhuno pāṭikaṅkhaṃ kalyāṇasahāyassa kalyāṇasampavaṅkassa—ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvessati, ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkarissati.
sn45.3:2.3.eng: A mendicant with good friends, companions, and associates can expect to develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path.

sn45.3:2.4.pli: Kathañca, sāriputta, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto kalyāṇasahāyo kalyāṇasampavaṅko ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāveti, ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkaroti?
sn45.3:2.4.eng: And how does a mendicant with good friends develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path?

sn45.3:3.1.pli: Idha, sāriputta, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ …pe… sammāsamādhiṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
sn45.3:3.1.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

sn45.3:3.2.pli: Evaṃ kho, sāriputta, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto kalyāṇasahāyo kalyāṇasampavaṅko ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāveti, ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkaroti.
sn45.3:3.2.eng: That’s how a mendicant with good friends develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path.

sn45.3:4.1.pli: Tadamināpetaṃ, sāriputta, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā sakalamidaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, yadidaṃ—kalyāṇamittatā kalyāṇasahāyatā kalyāṇasampavaṅkatā.
sn45.3:4.1.eng: And here’s another way to understand how good friends are the whole of the spiritual life.

sn45.3:4.2.pli: Mamañhi, sāriputta, kalyāṇamittaṃ āgamma jātidhammā sattā jātiyā parimuccanti; jarādhammā sattā jarāya parimuccanti; maraṇadhammā sattā maraṇena parimuccanti; sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā sattā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsehi parimuccanti.
sn45.3:4.2.eng: For, by relying on me as a good friend, sentient beings who are liable to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are freed from all these things.

sn45.3:4.3.pli: Iminā kho etaṃ, sāriputta, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā sakalamidaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, yadidaṃ—kalyāṇamittatā kalyāṇasahāyatā kalyāṇasampavaṅkatā”ti.
sn45.3:4.3.eng: This is another way to understand how good friends are the whole of the spiritual life.”

sn45.30:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā uttiyo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā uttiyo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn45.30:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Uttiya went up to the Buddha … and asked him,

sn45.30:1.3.pli: “idha mayhaṃ, bhante, rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
sn45.30:1.3.eng: “Just now, sir, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind.

sn45.30:1.4.eng: ‘The Buddha has spoken of the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

sn45.30:1.5.pli: Katame nu kho pañca kāmaguṇā vuttā bhagavatā’”ti?

sn45.30:1.7.pli: Pañcime kho, uttiya, kāmaguṇā vuttā mayā.
sn45.30:1.7.eng: I have spoken of these five kinds of sensual stimulation.

sn45.30:1.9.pli: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā,
sn45.30:1.9.eng: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn45.30:1.13.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā—
sn45.30:1.13.eng: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn45.30:1.14.pli: ime kho, uttiya, pañca kāmaguṇā vuttā mayā.
sn45.30:1.14.eng: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation that I’ve spoken of.

sn45.30:1.15.pli: Imesaṃ kho, uttiya, pañcannaṃ kāmaguṇānaṃ pahānāya ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvetabbo.
sn45.30:1.15.eng: The noble eightfold path should be developed to give up these five kinds of sensual stimulation.

sn45.30:1.16.eng: What is the noble eightfold path?

sn45.30:1.17.eng: It is right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.30:1.18.pli: Imesaṃ kho, uttiya, pañcannaṃ kāmaguṇānaṃ pahānāya ayaṃ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvetabbo”ti.
sn45.30:1.18.eng: This is the noble eightfold path that should be developed to give up these five kinds of sensual stimulation.”

sn45.31:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the wrong practice and the right practice.

sn45.31:1.5.eng: It is wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion.

sn45.31:1.6.eng: This is called the wrong practice.

sn45.31:1.8.eng: It is right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.31:1.9.eng: This is called the right practice.”

sn45.32:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you one practicing wrongly and one practicing rightly.

sn45.32:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco micchādiṭṭhiko hoti …pe… micchāsamādhi—
sn45.32:1.5.eng: It’s someone who has wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion.

sn45.32:1.6.eng: This is called one practicing wrongly.

sn45.32:1.8.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco sammādiṭṭhiko hoti …pe… sammāsamādhi—
sn45.32:1.8.eng: It’s someone who has right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.32:1.9.eng: This is called one practicing rightly.”

sn45.33:1.2.pli: “Yesaṃ kesañci, bhikkhave, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo viraddho, viraddho tesaṃ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī.
sn45.33:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, whoever has missed out on the noble eightfold path has missed out on the noble path to the complete ending of suffering.

sn45.33:1.3.pli: Yesaṃ kesañci, bhikkhave, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo āraddho, āraddho tesaṃ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī.
sn45.33:1.3.eng: Whoever has undertaken the noble eightfold path has undertaken the noble path to the complete ending of suffering.

sn45.33:1.4.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo?
sn45.33:1.4.eng: And what is the noble eightfold path?

sn45.33:1.5.eng: It is right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.33:1.6.pli: Yesaṃ kesañci, bhikkhave, ayaṃ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo viraddho, viraddho tesaṃ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī.
sn45.33:1.6.eng: Whoever has missed out on the noble eightfold path has missed out on the noble path to the complete ending of suffering.

sn45.33:1.7.pli: Yesaṃ kesañci, bhikkhave, ayaṃ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo āraddho, āraddho tesaṃ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo sammā dukkhakkhayagāmī”ti.
sn45.33:1.7.eng: Whoever has undertaken the noble eightfold path has undertaken the noble path to the complete ending of suffering.”

sn45.34:1.2.pli: “Aṭṭhime, bhikkhave, dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā apārā pāraṃ gamanāya saṃvattanti.
sn45.34:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, when these eight things are developed and cultivated they lead to going from the near shore to the far shore.

sn45.34:1.4.eng: They are right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.34:1.5.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭha dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā apārā pāraṃ gamanāya saṃvattantī”ti.
sn45.34:1.5.eng: When these eight things are developed and cultivated they lead to going from the near shore to the far shore.”

sn45.34:2.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn45.34:2.2.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
sn45.34:2.2.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn45.34:3.2.eng: who cross to the far shore.

sn45.34:4.1.eng: When the teaching is well explained,

sn45.34:4.3.eng: are the ones who will cross over

sn45.34:4.4.eng: Death’s dominion so hard to pass.

sn45.34:5.2.eng: an astute person should develop the bright.

sn45.34:5.4.eng: for the seclusion so hard to enjoy,

sn45.34:6.4.eng: should cleanse themselves of mental corruptions.

sn45.34:7.1.eng: And those whose minds are rightly developed

sn45.34:7.6.eng: they are quenched in this world.”

sn45.35:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the ascetic life and the fruits of the ascetic life.

sn45.35:1.4.eng: And what is the ascetic life?

sn45.35:1.5.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn45.35:1.6.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.35:1.7.eng: This is called the ascetic life.

sn45.35:1.8.eng: And what are the fruits of the ascetic life?

sn45.35:1.9.eng: The fruits of stream-entry, once-return, non-return, and perfection.

sn45.35:1.10.eng: These are called the fruits of the ascetic life.”

sn45.36:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the ascetic life and the goal of the ascetic life.

sn45.36:1.4.eng: And what is the ascetic life?

sn45.36:1.5.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn45.36:1.6.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.36:1.7.eng: This is called the ascetic life.

sn45.36:1.8.eng: And what is the goal of the ascetic life?

sn45.36:1.9.pli: Yo kho, bhikkhave, rāgakkhayo dosakkhayo mohakkhayo—
sn45.36:1.9.eng: The ending of greed, hate, and delusion.

sn45.36:1.10.eng: This is called the goal of the ascetic life.”

sn45.37:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you life as a brahmin and the fruits of life as a brahmin.

sn45.37:1.4.eng: And what is life as a brahmin?

sn45.37:1.5.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn45.37:1.6.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.37:1.7.eng: This is called life as a brahmin.

sn45.37:1.8.eng: And what are the fruits of life as a brahmin?

sn45.37:1.9.eng: The fruits of stream-entry, once-return, non-return, and perfection.

sn45.37:1.10.eng: These are called the fruits of life as a brahmin.”

sn45.38:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you life as a brahmin and the goal of life as a brahmin.

sn45.38:1.4.eng: And what is life as a brahmin?

sn45.38:1.5.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn45.38:1.6.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.38:1.7.eng: This is called life as a brahmin.

sn45.38:1.8.eng: And what is the goal of life as a brahmin?

sn45.38:1.9.pli: Yo kho, bhikkhave, rāgakkhayo dosakkhayo mohakkhayo—
sn45.38:1.9.eng: The ending of greed, hate, and delusion.

sn45.38:1.10.eng: This is called the goal of life as a brahmin.”

sn45.39:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the spiritual path and the fruits of the spiritual path.

sn45.39:1.4.eng: And what is the spiritual path?

sn45.39:1.5.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn45.39:1.6.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.39:1.7.eng: This is called the spiritual path.

sn45.39:1.8.eng: And what are the fruits of the spiritual path?

sn45.39:1.9.eng: The fruits of stream-entry, once-return, non-return, and perfection.

sn45.39:1.10.eng: These are called the fruits of the spiritual path.”

sn45.4:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
sn45.4:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.

sn45.4:1.3.pli: Addasā kho āyasmā ānando jāṇussoṇiṃ brāhmaṇaṃ sabbasetena vaḷavābhirathena sāvatthiyā niyyāyantaṃ.
sn45.4:1.3.eng: He saw the brahmin Jānussoṇi driving out of Sāvatthī in an all-white chariot drawn by mares.

sn45.4:1.4.pli: Setā sudaṃ assā yuttā honti setālaṅkārā, seto ratho, setaparivāro, setā rasmiyo, setā patodalaṭṭhi, setaṃ chattaṃ, setaṃ uṇhīsaṃ, setāni vatthāni, setā upāhanā, setāya sudaṃ vālabījaniyā bījīyati.
sn45.4:1.4.eng: The yoked horses were pure white, as were the ornaments, chariot, upholstery, reins, goad, and canopy. And his turban, robes, sandals were white, as was the chowry fanning him.

sn45.4:1.5.eng: When people saw it they exclaimed,

sn45.4:1.7.eng: It’s a vehicle fit for divinity!”

sn45.4:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn45.4:2.1.eng: Then Ānanda wandered for alms in Sāvatthī. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened, adding,

sn45.4:3.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, bhante, pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisiṃ.

sn45.4:3.2.pli: Addasaṃ khvāhaṃ, bhante, jāṇussoṇiṃ brāhmaṇaṃ sabbasetena vaḷavābhirathena sāvatthiyā niyyāyantaṃ.

sn45.4:3.3.pli: Setā sudaṃ assā yuttā honti setālaṅkārā, seto ratho, setaparivāro, setā rasmiyo, setā patodalaṭṭhi, setaṃ chattaṃ, setaṃ uṇhīsaṃ, setāni vatthāni, setā upāhanā, setāya sudaṃ vālabījaniyā bījīyati.

sn45.4:3.7.pli: Sakkā nu kho, bhante, imasmiṃ dhammavinaye brahmayānaṃ paññāpetun”ti?
sn45.4:3.7.eng: “Sir, can you point out a divine vehicle in this teaching and training?”

sn45.4:4.2.pli: “imasseva kho etaṃ, ānanda, ariyassa aṭṭhaṅgikassa maggassa adhivacanaṃ:
sn45.4:4.2.eng: “These are all terms for the noble eightfold path:

sn45.4:4.3.eng: ‘divine vehicle, or else ‘vehicle of truth’, or else ‘supreme victory in battle’.

sn45.4:5.1.pli: Sammādiṭṭhi, ānanda, bhāvitā bahulīkatā rāgavinayapariyosānā hoti, dosavinayapariyosānā hoti, mohavinayapariyosānā hoti.
sn45.4:5.1.eng: When right view is developed and cultivated it culminates with the removal of greed, hate, and delusion.

sn45.4:5.2.pli: Sammāsaṅkappo, ānanda, bhāvito bahulīkato rāgavinayapariyosāno hoti, dosavinayapariyosāno hoti, mohavinayapariyosāno hoti.

sn45.4:5.3.pli: Sammāvācā, ānanda, bhāvitā bahulīkatā rāgavinayapariyosānā hoti, dosa …pe… mohavinayapariyosānā hoti.

sn45.4:5.4.pli: Sammākammanto, ānanda, bhāvito bahulīkato rāgavinayapariyosāno hoti, dosa …pe… mohavinayapariyosāno hoti.

sn45.4:5.5.pli: Sammāājīvo, ānanda, bhāvito bahulīkato rāgavinayapariyosāno hoti, dosa …pe… mohavinayapariyosāno hoti.

sn45.4:5.6.pli: Sammāvāyāmo, ānanda, bhāvito bahulīkato rāgavinayapariyosāno hoti, dosa …pe… mohavinayapariyosāno hoti.

sn45.4:5.7.pli: Sammāsati, ānanda, bhāvitā bahulīkatā rāgavinayapariyosānā hoti, dosa …pe… mohavinayapariyosānā hoti.

sn45.4:5.8.pli: Sammāsamādhi, ānanda, bhāvito bahulīkato rāgavinayapariyosāno hoti, dosa …pe… mohavinayapariyosāno hoti.
sn45.4:5.8.eng: right immersion is developed and cultivated it culminates with the removal of greed, hate, and delusion.

sn45.4:6.1.pli: Iminā kho etaṃ, ānanda, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā imassevetaṃ ariyassa aṭṭhaṅgikassa maggassa adhivacanaṃ:
sn45.4:6.1.eng: This is a way to understand how these are all terms for the noble eightfold path:

sn45.4:6.2.eng: ‘vehicle of divine’, or else ‘vehicle of truth’, or else ‘supreme victory in battle’.”

sn45.4:6.3.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn45.4:7.1.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
sn45.4:7.1.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn45.4:8.2.eng: are always yoked to the shaft.

sn45.4:8.3.eng: Conscience is its pole, mind its strap,

sn45.4:9.2.eng: its axle is absorption, and energy its wheel.

sn45.4:9.3.eng: Equanimity and immersion are the carriage-shaft,

sn45.4:10.4.eng: as it rolls on to sanctuary from the yoke.

sn45.4:11.3.eng: The attentive leave the world in it,

sn45.40:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the spiritual path and the goal of the spiritual path.

sn45.40:1.4.eng: And what is the spiritual path?

sn45.40:1.5.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn45.40:1.6.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.40:1.7.eng: This is called the spiritual path.

sn45.40:1.8.eng: And what is the goal of the spiritual path?

sn45.40:1.9.pli: Yo kho, bhikkhave, rāgakkhayo dosakkhayo mohakkhayo—
sn45.40:1.9.eng: The ending of greed, hate, and delusion.

sn45.40:1.10.eng: This is called the goal of the spiritual path.”

sn45.41:0.2.eng: 5. Abbreviated Texts on Followers of Other Religions

sn45.41:1.2.pli: “Sace vo, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ puccheyyuṃ:
sn45.41:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, if wanderers who follow another religion were to ask you:

sn45.41:1.3.pli: ‘kimatthiyaṃ, āvuso, samaṇe gotame brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’ti, evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ evaṃ byākareyyātha:
sn45.41:1.3.eng: ‘Reverends, what’s the purpose of leading the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama?’ You should answer them like this:

sn45.41:1.4.eng: ‘The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is the fading away of greed.’

sn45.41:1.5.pli: Sace pana vo, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ puccheyyuṃ:
sn45.41:1.5.eng: If wanderers of other religions were to ask you:

sn45.41:1.6.pli: ‘atthi panāvuso, maggo, atthi paṭipadā rāgavirāgāyā’ti, evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ evaṃ byākareyyātha:
sn45.41:1.6.eng: ‘Is there a path and a practice for the fading away of greed?’ You should answer them like this:

sn45.41:1.7.pli: ‘atthi kho, āvuso, maggo, atthi paṭipadā rāgavirāgāyā’ti.
sn45.41:1.7.eng: ‘There is a path and a practice for the fading away of greed.’

sn45.41:1.8.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, maggo, katamā ca paṭipadā rāgavirāgāya?
sn45.41:1.8.eng: And what is that path, what is that practice for the fading away of greed?

sn45.41:1.9.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn45.41:1.10.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.41:1.11.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, maggo, ayaṃ paṭipadā rāgavirāgāyāti.
sn45.41:1.11.eng: This is the path, this is the practice for the fading away of greed.

sn45.41:1.12.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ evaṃ byākareyyāthā”ti.
sn45.41:1.12.eng: When questioned by wanderers of other religions, that’s how you should answer them.”

sn45.42-47:0.2.eng: 5. Abbreviated Texts on Followers of Other Religions

sn45.42-47:0.3.eng: Six Discourses on Giving Up Fetters, Etc.

sn45.42-47:1.1.pli: “Sace vo, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ puccheyyuṃ:
sn45.42-47:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, if wanderers who follow another religion were to ask you:

sn45.42-47:1.2.pli: ‘kimatthiyaṃ, āvuso, samaṇe gotame brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’ti, evaṃ puṭṭhā tumhe, bhikkhave, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ evaṃ byākareyyātha:
sn45.42-47:1.2.eng: ‘Reverends, what’s the purpose of leading the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama?’ You should answer them like this:

sn45.42-47:1.3.eng: ‘The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to give up the fetters.’ …

sn45.42-47:1.5.eng: ‘… to completely understand the course of time.’ …

sn45.42-47:1.6.pli: ‘āsavānaṃ khayatthaṃ kho, āvuso, bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’ti …pe…

sn45.42-47:1.7.eng: ‘… to realize the fruit of knowledge and freedom.’ …
